document.masterDocTitle: Diversity of Sternaspidae (Annelida: Terebellida) in the South China Sea, with descriptions of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Diversity of Sternaspidae (Annelida: Terebellida) in the South China Sea, with descriptions of four new species

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Sternaspis spinosa : Sluiter, 1882: 277
, Pl. 1, fig. 1.
Sendall & Salazar-Vallejo, 2013 : 47
–50, fig. 14.

(1 spec.), Xinying , Hainan Island , HBR- 3, approximate co-ordinate: 19°54’N , 109°30’E ,
15 Dec. 2010
.

Description. Largest specimen 43.3 mm long, 16.9 mm wide; left shield plate 5.58 long and 7.46 wide. Body pale or yellowish, introvert with similar pigmentation as abdomen, constriction or waist segments relaxed ( Figs 5 A; 6A).

Prostomium hemispherical, projected, translucent pale ( Figs 5 B; 6D). Eyespots not seen. Boundary distinct in side and back of prostomium. Peristomium whitish, flat, barely extending laterally and ventrally to anterior margin of first chaetiger. Mouth circular, projected, wider than prostomium, covered by minute papillae ( Figs 5 B; 6D).

First three chaetigers each with 18–25 bronze hooks per side. Hooks tapering to sharp points, sub-distally darker, gradually shortened towards ventrolateral side ( Figs 5 B, C; 6D). Introvert covered by minute papillae ( Figs 5 C; 6D). Genital papillae conical, distally truncate, protruding ventro-laterally from inter-segmental groove between segments 7 and 8 ( Fig. 5 A). Anterior abdomen with 7 segments; papillae minute, evenly distributed ( Fig. 6 A), eroded in larger specimens ( Fig. 5 A). Capillaries not seen.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Sternaspis spinosa
Sluiter
, 1882
. A. Complete specimen (MBM020948) in ventral view, branchiae removed, arrows pointing to genital papillae; B, C. Anterior end (MBM020947) in ventral and left-lateral view; D. Branchial plates (MBM198745) in rear end view, branchiae removed; E–H. Shield morphology of four specimens (E: MBM020948; F: MBM020947; G: MBM198745; H: MBM020932). Scale bars: 5 mm (A), 0.5 mm (B) and 1 mm (C–H).

FIGURE 6. Juveniles of
Sternaspis spinosa
Sluiter, 1882
. A. Three specimens (A1–A3: MBM020926); B. Shield morphology of specimen A1; C. Shield morphology of specimen A3; D. Anterior end of specimen A3 in ventral view; E. Branchial plates of specimen A3 in rear end view, branchiae removed. Scale bars: 2 mm (A) and 0.5 mm (B–E).

subSubSection.paragraph: Ventro-caudal shield brick red, darker in central area; at least twice wider than long. Concentric lines welldefined ( Fig. 5 E–H). Anterior margins angular, anterior depression deep; anterior keels covered by translucent integument layer. Suture only visible in anterior region, fused posteriorly into a shallow furrow. Lateral margins rounded, smooth, expanded laterally, reduced posteriorly. Fan slightly ribbed, truncate, not extending beyond posterolateral corners; margin crenulated, without a median notch ( Fig. 5 E–H).

Marginal chaetae including 10 lateral fascicles and 5 posterior ones ( Fig. 5 E–H); lateral fascicles successively longer from anterior to posterior, last three bundles close together, chaetae in shallow curve; posterior fascicles similar in length, chaetae in linear arrangement. Peg chaetae tapering, with stout base. A small fascicle of very long, delicate capillary chaetae, inserted in edge of peg chaetae, 2–3 times as long as posteriormost lateral fascicle.
A fascicle of shorter capillary chaetae located between peg chaetae and outermost lateral fascicle, 3 times as long as posterior chaetae.

Branchiae abundant, inserted on two plates. Branchial filaments slender, spiraled or curled; inter-branchial papillae long, curled, with fine sediment particles. Branchial plates long, widely divergent, distal portion narrow ( Figs 5 D; 6E).

Variation. The ventro-caudal shield varies in two aspects. First, the shields in most individuals are laterally expanded with rounded lateral margins ( Fig. 5 F–H), while in a few other individuals the lateral margins are straight with relatively better developed anterolateral and posterolateral corners ( Fig. 5 E). Second, the radial ribs are usually present in the fan and form a slightly crenulated posterior margin ( Fig. 5 E–G), but may also be indistinct forming a smooth margin ( Fig. 5 H).

Juvenile shield. Immature specimens illustrated in Figure 6 were collected together with the adults of
S. spinosa
. They have morphologically similar ventro-caudal shields and branchial plates ( Fig. 6 B, C, E), and are thus regarded as juveniles of
S. spinosa
. Their shields are mainly reddish-orange, with one or two annulated concentric bands near the margin. The shield width is not significantly greater than its length ( Fig. 6 B, C). The radial ribs are poorly defined especially in the smaller body ( Fig. 6 B). The suture extends throughout the shield. The marginal regions of the shield are covered by whitish filamentous papillae. As the body size increases, the radial stripes appear on the lateral plates, and the main ribs also become visible ( Fig. 6 C).

Distribution.
Sternaspis spinosa
is widely distributed in the tropical Western Pacific, ranging from the South China Sea (water depth 7–93 m , Fig. 1 ) southwards to the Coral Sea off Australia . It is the most common and abundant sternaspid in the northern South China Sea. According to our material examined, the distribution of this species is generally not beyond 23 degrees North.

Remarks.
Sternaspis spinosa
had long been a confusing species because its original description was brief and its type material was unknown until Sendall & Salazar-Vallejo (2013) designated a neotype collected from the Bay of Batavia, Java. Our specimens agree well with the neotype in general morphology. The differences include that the anterior keels are exposed and the suture is visible throughout the shield in the neotype, while in our material the anterior keels are covered by translucent integument and the suture is only visible in the anterior region and fused posteriorly. A possible reason is that the integument layer covering the shield was partly corroded in the old specimen which was collected in 1889 and designated as the neotype.

The species can be identified by a combination of characters as follows: the shield width is twice larger than its length; the concentric lines are conspicuous and the ribs are slightly developed; and the posterior margin is truncate without a median notch.
